content.description:
Devious corner cruxes with intriguing moves and a tricky roof on perfect rock about sums it up! A must do! Start out with some techno stems and meander up to a weird section where if a certain hold were not to exist, we might have a heinous 5.13ish despo crux. Don't let the location of one bolt fool you... 
 The roof move is a thinker. Don't bash yer shins!

Middle of cliff, leftmost left-facing corner with lots of bolts.
9 bolts, 2 pins equalized with a tied runner (which needs to be replaced; a double-length runner will work)

The route's name is a cool mash-up of the FA's last names... 
  
 This is a fun, short exercise in laybacks and underclings. At the start, good gear will be had but you'll need to go up a bit to get it (be mindful of that big hollow sounding block you're putting pro in). As the line arcs left, obvious underclings with good footwork take you to the small ledge and the anchor. If you want more, there's a mixed gear/bolts extension to another anchor (Four Inches Radder, 5.11).  

The rightmost left-facing dihedral on the wall.
Gear to 2" but some people may want doubles around finger sizes...

The first half of the Querculator (stop at the anchor halfway up the wall). Delicate, then burly.

The leftmost bolt line at Quercus.
6 bolts

Pull past a roof onto a right leaning crack leading to a stance below the polished face. Climb through the improbable looking bulge, and pull past horizontal cracks and edges to the top. Avoid the temptation to traverse right onto Prince of Thieves as it is an independent line. Similar in nature to The Oracle, just a bit harder. The gear on the upper face is a bit tricky but generally good.



Left side of the wall, just left of A Prince Among Thieves. Independent anchor

Singles BD 00 to 4”, RPs, small/med stoppers, several runners.

Sick technical near vertical face climbing. Starts off with some technical 11+ climbing then it’s full on technical foot work and tiny hand holds to gain bigger holds after the crux but a tricky section just after this could spit you off. Sonnie did the FA and graded it 5.13+, then Steve Townsend broke a hold at the crux which he says made it harder. Marc Bourbon later did the 3rd ascent and proposed 14a then the next year I did the 4th ascent and confirmed 14a. Video Here

Right of vorpal
Bokts

This is a fantastic and devious all-gear line of discontinuous arching seams and edges. The route brilliantly pieces together with just enough pro to keep you off the deck (as soon as you get your first pieces, that is); luckily you can stand on your feet a lot to figure it out. The gear is not totally obvious at times and needs exact placement. It's all there for a compitent leader but even still, an onsight lead could potentially become "R or X" rated if you don't pro it just right. Great movement on interesting, less than vertical rock with a couple defined cruxes. There is a big run out section up high but on easier terrain. If in doubt, toprope first...

Just right of A Prince Among Thieves
A set of cams from .4" to 2" including extra .6" to .1" (I found green to red Aliens to be a nice fit), small to medium nuts/offsets, some runners, attentive belayer

A very fun line on great rock climbs halfway up Channeling Your Wheaties and with a long reach bust out right through the roof past a bolt. Clip a second bolt and using good footwork and body positioning brings you to a hold at a horizontal and sets you up for the engaging shallow crack section. Work your way up the seam, making sure you eye the proper spot to place the correct piece "just right", and up to another horizontal. Finish it off to the top of the sloping ledge and then the anchor.

Same start as Channeling Your Wheaties
Gear up to 2" for starting the corner. Above there are 2 bolts and available placements for a small cam down to a medium offset brass nut. The book says SR but I took some doubles which I was happy to have.

Apparently the name (with proper pronounciation) might be a spin-off of a classic Yosemite pitch on the Rostrum... Interesting climbing past some cool polish takes you past 5 bolts to a shallow left facing corner where an optional small cam could be placed. Either clip the intermediate chains and call it a 5.10, or crank out a cruxy move clearing the overhang to some crimps and a tricky clip. (I believe this may have been an abandoned route from years ago and the bolts only were replaced?) From the ground, this upper part looks super run out but it's really not bad at all and the bolts protect the hard moves and in between it is way easier. Another optional cam may be placed before clipping the last bolt. Finish with some cool and funky moves up a shallow layback and then up to the anchor. Leftmost route on the cliff. 7 protection bolts, intermediate and upper anchor.
Optional cams from .5" - .75"

Techy off-vertical (slabby) crimps up a clean wall.
Near the top, traverse a horizontal to reach a vertical crack out left, gaining the ledge.
5-ish bolts

Near the right end of the cliff, just right of a left-facing corner. Merges with a mixed route that climbs said corner and exits right on bolts (Overdose)
5(ish) bolts

An absolutely smashing wall stacked with approximately 12 routes, some of which are extensions. The wall has it all...100% gear, mixed and fully bolted lines up to 13+. With only one singular 5.10 route, this is not an intermediate climber's wall, it caters to 5.12 and harder climbers. Quercus Cliff sits in an idyllic location perched up above Lakeside in the Woods, just off the new Loop Trail in a well cleared out nook.
